(9 comments)
can we return the url to help client generate qrcode for authenticator?

clients can easily generate QR code from secret key or WebGUI can generate QR code from secret key.
Redfish schema does not support returning URL with QR code
is there any key called <user> or is it <str>?
Its just username string
Done
nit: As different countries do this in different order, I prefer just "June 10, 2204"
Done
nit: missing "." at end.
Done
nit: make consistent capitalization throughout document.
Done

I suspect you have markdown formatting issues here (check markdown-lint warnings from CI).  Generally we shouldn't have free-standing references but actually reference to them in the document itself.  What is the motivation for someone to follow these links?

Example:  

On lines 25 change to something like this:

```
...specified in [RFC 6238][rfc-6238].
```

And then change line 33 to:

```
[rfc-6238]: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6238
```
Done
This seems like an implementation detail? I do think "MFA must be disabled by default" is a valid requirement though.
Done
Maybe reword a bit? "System administrator must be able to configure specific accounts to bypass MFA"
Done
How?
That seems like something for the implementation section
yeah removed requirement 4 & 5
nit: "User _is_ expected"?
Done
This doesn't sound like a Requirement?  Is this somehow related to or a continuation of Requirement 4?
Maybe a bit more on these 2 options in the background section too?
removed these requirement 4 and 5 from requirement section
Done

How?

Is this really a requirement?  "_should_" word doesn't imply this is a requirement.

What happens if the BMC time gets out of sync with reality and now you can't log in as an administrator to fix it?
BMC time should be in sync with mobile device where TOTP gets generated otherwise OTP wont work. there is some time slew which pam module tolerate for network delays..
This aren't Requirements but are limitations?
yes agreed
Done
nit: Prior _to_ logging in?
Done
nit: spelling
They work on Apple as well I believe (I have the google authenticator on my iphone)?
Done
yeah you are right.
Uh...  I don't think most people are going to like this.  Can you clarify what you mean by "configured as required"?
I mean pam configuration required to use google-authenticator pam module

When the MFA is enabled, and there are secret keys for the user, then PAM module will consume the google authenticator's library plugin. 
This will be ignored if the MFA is disabled/bypassed for that user.
How does a dbus interface get presented to the user?
Do we need to do what we do with other passwords and write this to a file vs. sending unencrypted over d-bus?

yeah that's the plan, dont want to share secret key over D-bus
secret key will generated and kept user's home directory and bmcweb reads secret key from the file and return secret key to redfish client.
Done
How??  Is there something added to the Redfish response (as part of the standard) that indicates this?
yes, new redfish registry "GenerateSecretKeyRequired" will be returned as a redfish response similar to "PasswordChangeRequired"

Is there any possibility that the secret key gets lost and the owner gets locked out of their machine?  What is the mitigation for that?

Does this not affect admin accounts?
There is possibility of lockout scenarios if user enable MFA for itself and lost key, if system has another user with administrator privilege then it can be recovered by disabling MFA of that user.
You've mentioned "oauth tool" a few times.  Is this something standardized?  Anything we can share a reference to?
yeah, its linux tool https://man.archlinux.org/man/oathtool.1.en
Done
Can we point to the specific Redfish authentication spec that defines how this is done?
please refer "Token" parameter at https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/Session.v1_7_2.json
Done

How do these BypassTypes get communicated to PAM?  I'm having trouble understanding how we are planning to write the PAM config such that these can be handled.  Can you elaborate on that?

PAM configs are usually per-service.  I don't know how we enable TOTP in the PAM config but then allow certain users to bypass it.

pam-google-authentictor.so will added to PAM files. 
Actually Google Authenticator PAM module looks for user's secret key file in user's home directory during authentication. If user bypassed MFA then secret key file will be removed.

> PAM module looks for user's secret key file in user's home directory during authentication. 

These are important parts of the design that were omitted, and need added.  Presumably PUM is responsible for maintaining these secret files?

This doesn't exist in the Base message registry.  Did you make this up?

https://redfish.dmtf.org/registries/Base.1.18.1.json

I have proposed this in DMTF forum and its approved
coming up Base.1.19.json will have this new registry.
Done
why is this named as GenerateSecretKeyResponse?
This is as per redfish schema, GenerateSecretKeyResponse is complex type of GenerateSecretKey action response
Done
Will the user be restricted to only generate the secret key in this flow or could they do whatever they wish on this first login?
Since MFA enabled, User will be restricted to generate the secret key in this flow.
Done
Please rephrase and add more details
Done

I made it partway through the review, and came to the conclusion that this design needs more effort put in.

Almost every reference to Redfish properties or messages don't exist in the currently published schemas (despite a few actually calling out a version).  If you're publishing "new" potential things that could be added to the DMTF standard, please state that explicitly, but what it looks like is that someone wrote up an idealized OTP flow without actually checking what ended up in the Redfish specification.

The examples of Redfish requests to do the actions are incorrect, and the internal details on how this actually works inside pam reference methods that don't seem to match the PAM documentation or existing bmcweb code.  There's a lack of details on how the internal OpenBMC daemons communicate aside from some references to us adding new interfaces to dbus (which ideally would be in a phosphor-dbus-interfaces review).

I completely understand if some of these details aren't known at this time, and if you want to start pushing patches under an option flag (that we'll likely need anyway), that seems like a much better place to start and iterate on than a design doc.  Said another way, I don't really see a "change" in design here aside from adding the google pam module.  We're using the existing user manager service to handle a new type of user management, using the existing dbus paths, and adding 2-3 new properties in accordance with the DMTF specification.  I suspect we can get that done without having to have this much design, and just get agreement that:

1. We'll pull in the google pam module.
2. We'll add interfaces to support OTP (in a PDI review).
3. We'll add bmcweb changes that match the Redfish spec and are managed in a similar way to how the existing user parameters are managed.
4. The option will be selectable at compile time.
5. Secrets will be stored on disk.


If we agree on those things, I suspect this document can be much... much shorter, and we can focus on actually defining the implementation correctly in code.

Please specify this as actual requirements.  "Support GoogleAuthenticator Time-based One-time Password" could mean we implement an authenticator server, or a token generator, neither of which i suspect you intended.
How?  What interfaces will they use?  At compile time or runtime?  I suspect you need to call out that this needs to be enabled/disabled at both runtime and compile time.

?  This seems like an odd requirement.  Can we back this up with something that specifies that this is acceptable.  Ideally with something like: https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet.html

Or alternatively, I suspect that we need to invert this requirement, and make it "a user may enable two factor auth for their account."

This is as per DMTF schema where there is "MultiFactorAuth" configuration at account service level and  each user will have MFA bypass configuration at each user account 
https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/ManagerAccount.v1_12_1.yaml
When I say "back this up" I'd like to see a link reference to a security authority that this is the right thing to do.

Remove.  We will follow the existing DMTF privilege registry like we do for all other things.  If you want to change that, and have openbmc maintain its own registry, that's a much larger scope than this doc.  Either the existing dmtf registry meets this requirement, and this is noop, or it doesn't and this requirement belongs to DMTF.
Done
Remove.  This isn't a requirement of the implementation.  The BMC already has mechanisms for keeping time, that I don't think you plan on changing.

right, TOTP based authentication based on time on the machine.
If mobile device which generates TOTP token does not match with the BMC time then
TOTP won't work and authentication fails.
so captured that point here..

That's a good thing to capture in background as a way this can fail, but it's not a requirement.

Another thing you might mention is the fact that a number of BMCs don't include a hardware RTC, so do we need to have special provisions for only allowing OTP when we know the time as been set correctly?
This seems like it should go in background.  It mentions nothing about the "design" and only walks through a normal workflow.
Done
This needs more details.  How will requirements like some users have OTP requirements, and other don't be implemented?
this is based on secret key file setup at user's home directory for each user when TOTP authentication enabled
Right, but not all users require OTP, others don't.  It's not clear how "enhancing" the existing pam configuration files accomplishes that requirement.
What is this?

There is MFA Bypass configuration for each user account, so TOTP authentication can be bypassed for specific users.
MFABypass D-bus interface holds corresponding configuration on D-bus and persists
Can you change this to make clear which of these interfaces exist at global scope, and which interfaces exist at user scope?  Right now it's quite confusing.
what does "CreateSecretKey" do?

This method call google-authenticator to create TOTP secret key for that user.
secret will be generated & placed in a file under user's home directory,
same secret key will be used to verify totp for that user authentication
Answer in your document please.  Your answer makes sense, but your doc just says there's an interface with a method, it doesn't specify what it does or now it works.
typo.
what interface/path are all these things implemented on?  Providing an example might be better here.
Done
Not nearly enough detail here.  What resources are we adding support for?  Which properties?
These 3 all read like a task list.  HOW does "bmcweb implement" these things?  what does it implement of the redfish spec?

GenerateSecretKeyRequired doesn't exist as a valid Redfish base regisry response.  Is it possible you need to discuss your workflow with DMTF?  Or is there something I'm missing.


This line item needs way more details on what's being implemented, and how this is going to work.  As written, I'm not even sure what we intend to implement in the user-facing Redfish API, much less how the internals work.

yeah that's right. GenerateSecretKeyRequired does not exist in DMTF schemas.
I have proposed this new registry to DMTF
Please make that clear in your doc somewhere that we are operating on _potential_ schema changes that aren't published yet.

This action doesn't exist anywhere in DMTF documentation, and based on the fact that I don't see a namespace attached, I'm assuming you just made it up?  What am I missing?

https://github.com/search?q=repo%3ADMTF%2FRedfish-Publications%20GenerateSecretKey&type=code

yes, this does not exist in DMTF schemas
I have proposed this new action to DMTF.
Same answer.
Not a design element.  Possibly a requirement.
Done
"Users expected" isn't a design.  How does bmcweb accept these OTP tokens?  What happens if they're not provided?
Done

Please update "MFA token parameter" to actually reference the Redfish documentation.  Redfish "parameters" are passed via query parameters, which this certainly wouldn't be.  If you meant "Property", you should specify the exact name of the property, including the namespace.
Done

pam_authenticate doesn't accept a password or a token.  Either update this with the correct API you plan to use, or remove from this design (as it's probably detail that's better handled in code review).

yeah, seems password passed to pam_start() call 
Done
This kind of detail about what properties we're implementing needs handled above.  Also keep in mind that this example wouldn't work as written, as there's no SecretKey included.
yeah I agree, i have captured these examples as per suggested/proposed schemas to DMTF
Can we update the examples so they would actually work as written?

?

https://github.com/DMTF/Redfish-Publications/tree/main/registries

are the existing registries.  GenerateSecretKeyRequired doesn't show up.

yeah this registry is not present in redfish schemas.
I have suggested this new registry to DMTF.
HTTP servers don't "Throw".  Please update this with correct terminology and properties that reference the redfish standard.
Done

Another place where this key doesn't exist:

https://github.com/DMTF/Redfish-Publications/blob/main/registries/Base.1.8.1.json

Updated as an example here.
I have suggested this new registry to DMTF.

This doesn't exist in the ManagerAccount Schema.

https://github.com/DMTF/Redfish-Publications/blob/main/csdl/ManagerAccount_v1.xml

yes, this action does not exist in DMTF schemas
I have proposed this new action to DMTF.

Hi Edtanous

Thank you so much for your review and feedback on this design.
yes i have referred redfish properties which are not present in standard redfish.
These redfish examples looks incorrect as per current standard DMTF schemas,
but i have suggested and proposed all these redfish schemas in DMTF forum.
I have worked with DMTF community for last couples of weeks on this proposal.
Mostly all these redfish schemas will be present in next DMTF release.
I will keep this design doc updated as per next standard redfish release.

I agree that we are just adding google PAM module and implementing D-bus & redfish spec to enable two factor authentication. I am good with the agreement you have mentioned to get this work done, will continue work on implementation.

Pull google pam module
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/73216

D-bus interface commit
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/72602

> yes i have referred redfish properties which are not present in standard redfish.


In the future, a lot of time and effort would be saved if you put that in your design doc on submission.  I'm happy to review in-progress stuff, and I have access to the DMTF internals, but when designs are pushed that don't state that, I have to assume they're using existing schemas that the public can see.

When you're creating designs in an open source project based around not yet approved things, you need to document exactly what changes you're expecting to see from the specification, so we know that's what's happening.  Not everyone has access to the DMTF github.
